claim: If the youngest patient who underwent any recorded medical examination in the database had presented without any neurologic complaints, the diagnosis would have been postponed by six months.
extra_info: The larger the birthday value, the younger the person is, and vice versa; symptoms observed refers to the symptoms is not NULL
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim using 'If... had presented... the diagnosis would have been postponed' language. It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
This claim is a counterfactual — it describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If the youngest patient... had presented without any neurologic complaints, the diagnosis would have been postponed by six months."

This uses classic counterfactual language ("If X had happened... Y would have happened"). The database records what actually occurred, not what would have happened under hypothetical changes to a patient's presentation. There is no way to verify from the data whether a diagnosis "would have been postponed by six months" in an alternate scenario.

Per the workflow rules, counterfactual claims must always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

```json

It describes a hypothetical scenario that cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. Counterfactual claims are always NOT ENOUGH INFO."}
